TOP Where is VBrick's focus? The Enterprise Market. Competitors tend to focus on what they perceive as the "big markets", including Hollywood movie distribution, Pay-Per-View Internet Streaming, DVD Content Creation, and consumer markets for "Personal Video Recorders" and "Time Shifting Recorders" or content consumption. The Enterprise market can be defined as owners of their own digital networks, who also use pubic networks (the Internet) for economy, to communicate with a target audience. From a video streaming perspective, the Enterprise market tends to have a smaller target viewing audience (100's, or 1,000's) than the consumer market (100,000's or 1,000,000's). Enterprises include Corporations, Educational Institutions, Government Agencies and Departments, and other organizations with a professional staff and a need to communicate in a better, faster, or more compelling way. It is important to reiterate that "Internet Streaming" is a method Enterprise's use to reach their audience. This is different from an organization who's main objective is to provide video content using the Internet. The latter is a peripheral VBrick market. However, some vendors are taking PC's (complete with Windows OS), adding software, and offering these as "appliances" systems. Among these are Pinnacle, Optibase, Winnov, and others. TOP Microsoft, Real, Apple, Sorenson, and so many others claim 'high quality', and I've seen really good video at low rates. How does the VBrick's MPEG-4 quality compare? There will always be a trade-off between proprietary and standards. Generally, proprietary will always be 'better' for a given application. This is true because one vendor, acting alone, can make improvements that other vendors cannot implement. This is not unique to the video industry...for example Cisco may tell you that their special routing technology will do some useful tricks but if you use it, you cannot interoperate with other routers or switches in your network. For many, it is good practice to avoid proprietary whenever possible. In the case of MPEG-4, the quality of the encoding is based on proprietary techniques while still meeting the standards. This has do with the how well each vendor's approach to compression deals with motion, delay, rate control, audio/video sync, and many other factors. But the biggest cause for confusion has do with the live vs. multiple-pass encoding. You can indeed take a 10-minute video, and spend many hours compressing it to a file on your hard disk. The result of such "multiple pass encoding" can be excellent, and this is what is shown at trade shows and customer demos. For a fair evaluation of VBrick's MPEG-4 vs. any other solution, you must conduct live, real time, low delay encoding and decoding. Given this condition, VBrick's MPEG-4 is equal to or superior to any other MPEG-4 encoder today. When you compare MPEG-4 to Real, Microsoft or other proprietary encoder, the proprietary solutions may be judged superior in video quality. However, the difference is quality is apparent only to the most careful viewer and only on a side-by-side comparison. But it is not correct to compare "MPEG-4" to anything! "MPEG-4" defines many profiles and layers which are different for each application. VBrick initially supports simple profile (the most widely supported and interoperable profile). Other profiles, such as advanced simple, and H.264, will provide even higher quality at a given bit rate. TOP Competitors offer multi-rate encoding that allow one product to deliver streams at different rates to different audiences. What is VBrick's position? Multi-rate encoding, as promoted by Microsoft and Real doesn't work well and is rarely used. Among the issues are 1) client viewers get confused when they are on a corporate LAN, 2) an error in the stream affects everyone and 3) frame sizes must be the same for all videos. One VBrick appliance can be configured two deliver to streams at different encoding rates. With this superior approach, each stream is truly independent, and clients can simply choose the stream that is best for their connection speed. In addition, each stream can be simultaneously delivered via both RTSP unicast, multicast, and directed unicast. This approach provides the ultimate in reliability and flexibility in a system that always works. TOP Does VBrick have a strategy for delivery of video over wireless? "Wireless" is presumed to be wireless delivery of IP packets over 802.11b, 802.11a, microwave, satellite, optical laser, or cell phones. VBrick's MPEG-1 and MPEG-2 products are regularly used over high bandwidth wireless connections today. MPEG-4, in particular delivered via RTSP unicasting, may be viewed on wireless desktops and PDA's. From a video network perspective, there is little difference between wired and wireless, except that wireless must use low bandwidth...which MPEG-4 products now provide. VBrick is not in the business delivering video to 'cell phones' at speeds of 9600 bps. To the extent a cell phone, or any device, is capable of receiving standards-compliant MPEG-4 at any supported rate (e.g. 56 Kbps and up), VBrick is a good choice for the video source. Prior to the MPEG-4 product, wireless delivery of video was limited to point-to-point connections due to the bandwidth and because multicasting over wireless is not always supported. With the MPEG-4 product, direct wireless delivery to desktops, laptops, and (future) PDA's is a target application. TOP What are the Win Themes? It depends on what you want to do. If you want to encode a video to disk, create 'content', author or manipulate video, a PC with software is an excellent solution (however, there are dedicated devices that serves this market too). If you want to stream live video, an appliance is superior for several reasons. First, customers will not have to suffer the "blue screen of death" reliability issues. Second, the use of a PC for streaming is often false economy...one might think they are going to do multiple things with the computer while the reality is that it must become dedicated for streaming only (what do you think will happen to your stream if you suddenly start editing a Word document on that same computer?). Third, an appliance is quite rugged and portable, allowing it to be placed virtually anywhere. Finally, there are various 'soft' issues that a VBrick appliance addresses, such as very quiet operation (PC's usually have very noisy fans), easy installation, easy use, the fact that you cannot accidentally load some software that breaks the streaming capabilities, robustness and reliability, and its inherent resistance to computer viruses, worms, and bugs. For customers with strong feelings that they want a PC software solution, the "appliance vs. PC" debate is not one VBrick is likely to win. Key point: Although a VBrick does far more than a "video capture card", for certain applications and for customers familiar with Osprey or Winnov cards, VBrick can be positioned as a "Network Attached Video Capture Card for MPEG-4".
